auto_merge.commit_message:
Similarly to declaring freethreading support, this only affects code
generation for what the module declares.

It also generates warnings for a few things that I know to be dubious.
auto_merge.commit_title: Allow the user to declare subinterpreter support (#6513)

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Similarly to declaring freethreading support, this only affects code generation for what the module declares.

It also generates warnings for a few things that I know to be dubious.

comment_data.body:
`'False'` looks like an accident at first sight and weird at second. Better use a clear distinction like `'false'` instead to leave a note of your own consideration and make readers think less. But then, why not just `'no'`?
```suggestion
    'subinterpreters_compatible': 'no',
```

```suggestion
    If set to ``shared_gil`` or ``own_gil``, then Cython sets the
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -870,6 +870,17 @@ Cython code.  Here is the list of currently supported directives:
     is still experimental itself, this is also an experimental directive that
     might be changed or removed in future releases.
 
+``subinterpreters_compatible``  (False / shared_gil / own_gil), *default=False*
+    If set to ``shared_gil`` or ``own_gil`` then Cython sets the

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                "This variable is not currently in the per-interpreter module state "
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1627,6 +1627,20 @@ def declare_var(self, name, type, pos,
             if not (type.is_pyobject and not type.is_extension_type):
                 raise InternalError(
                     "Non-cdef global variable is not a generic Python object")
+        if (is_cdef and visibility != "extern"
+                and self.directives['subinterpreters_compatible'] != "False"):
+            extra_warning = ""
+            pyobject_warning = ""
+            if type.is_pyobject:
+                extra_warning = ".\nPython objects should not be shared between interpreters"
+                pyobject_warning = "Python "
+            warning(
+                pos,
+                f"Global cdef {pyobject_warning}variable used with subinterpreter support enabled.\n"
+                "This variable is  not currently in the per-interpreter module state "

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                extra_warning = "\nPython objects should not be shared between interpreters"
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1627,6 +1627,20 @@ def declare_var(self, name, type, pos,
             if not (type.is_pyobject and not type.is_extension_type):
                 raise InternalError(
                     "Non-cdef global variable is not a generic Python object")
+        if (is_cdef and visibility != "extern"
+                and self.directives['subinterpreters_compatible'] != "False"):
+            extra_warning = ""
+            pyobject_warning = ""
+            if type.is_pyobject:
+                extra_warning = ".\nPython objects should not be shared between interpreters"

comment_data.body:
We already have more than one sentence here, so no reason not to have a dot at the end of the second as well.
```suggestion
                "but this will likely change in future releases." +
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1627,6 +1627,20 @@ def declare_var(self, name, type, pos,
             if not (type.is_pyobject and not type.is_extension_type):
                 raise InternalError(
                     "Non-cdef global variable is not a generic Python object")
+        if (is_cdef and visibility != "extern"
+                and self.directives['subinterpreters_compatible'] != "False"):
+            extra_warning = ""
+            pyobject_warning = ""
+            if type.is_pyobject:
+                extra_warning = ".\nPython objects should not be shared between interpreters"
+                pyobject_warning = "Python "
+            warning(
+                pos,
+                f"Global cdef {pyobject_warning}variable used with subinterpreter support enabled.\n"
+                "This variable is  not currently in the per-interpreter module state "
+                "but this will likely change in future releases" +

commit.message:
Allow the use to declare subinterpreter support

Similarly to declaring freethreading support, this only affects
code generation for what the module declares.

It also generates warnings for a few things that I know to be
dubious.

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Allow the user to declare subinterpreter support
